Eiffel Tower.passage:
1
Eiffel Tower is a wrought iron lattice tower located on the Champ de Mars in Paris, 124m (400 feet) tall. It is the tallest structure in Paris and 9th tallest in the world. The tower has 12 levels accessible by 2 escalators. There are 2 elevators, as well. It is possible to visit the first two levels without an admission ticket, but the upper levels require admission. Eiffel Tower was built by Gustave Eiffel, a renowned engineer. Construction began in 1887 and was finished 12 years later. The tower was originally built for the 1889 Exposition Universelle in Paris.

qae_pairs.question: What is the name of the event that Eiffel Tower was built for?
qae_pairs.explanation: Exposition Universelle is a French term that means Worlds Fair. It is an event that is held in Paris every 10 years. The first Exposition Universelle was held in 1889 and the Eiffel Tower was built for this event.

qae_pairs.question: What is the name of the year the Eiffel Tower was built?
qae_pairs.explanation: 1889 was the year the Eiffel Tower was built.

qae_pairs.explanation: Eiffel Tower is the name of the tower, and Paris is the name of the city it is located in.

qae_pairs.question: Who built the Eiffel Tower?
qae_pairs.explanation: Gustave Eiffel was a renowned engineer who designed the Eiffel Tower. He was originally asked to build it for the 1889 Exposition Universelle in Paris.

Taj Mahal.passage: (also known as Shah Jahan or Shah Jahan the Great) (Persian: تجامل مسجل / Taj Mahal "Palace of Light" ) is a mausoleum located in New Delhi, India, completed in 1632. The construction was ordered by the Mughal emperor Shah Jahan in memory of his favorite wife Mumtaz Mahal ("Mistress of the world", Persian: ألاك / ąalīk). It is considered one of the most iconic architectural and engineering feats of the 17th century world and is located at the south-western end of the Red Fort in the city. This monument is constructed out of marble and white lime and is considered one of the most iconic architectural and engineering feats of the 17th century world. It is located at the south-western end of the Red Fort in the city. It is a mausoleum built in memory of the Mughal emperor's beloved wife Mumtaz Mahal. It is a striking architectural achievement of the 17th century world. It is made of marble and white lime.

qae_pairs.question: What is the capital of India?
qae_pairs.explanation: New Delhi is the capital of India. It is located in the northern part of the country and is spread over an area of 1,484 square kilometers. It is the largest city in the country and is home to over 20 million people. It is the home of the Indian government and is the center of all major government offices. It is also home to many monuments and tourist attractions, including the Red Fort, the Qutab Minar, and the India Gate.

qae_pairs.explanation: The father of Taj Mahal is Shah Jahan.

Great Wall of China.passage:
(I've inserted some relevant parts in parentheses and bolded some words that I'm guessing are more commonly known in Chinese history):
"The Great Wall of China is a series of fortification systems built along the edge of the country, usually using stone or brick. The name 'Great Wall' was likely coined by the 8th-century Persian ruler Bahraman in his famous poem 'Peril and the Perilous,' which referred to Chinese defenses against attacks from nomadic tribes from the north. The wall stretches about 7,500 miles (12,000 km) and is estimated to have taken up to 2,000 years to build. It has been continuously maintained and improved by the Chinese over the centuries. The Great Wall was built along the Ming Dynasty (1368–1644) and extended in the 18th century by Qianlong (1744–1795), the 2nd emperor of the Qing Dynasty (1644–1911). The Ming Dynasty's Great Wall, with its more than 20,000 watchtowers, was constructed in large numbers during the reign of Ming Dynasty Emperor Tung Ching, which lasted from 1392 to 1644. The Ming dynasty's wall extended 8,100 miles and had 2,500 miles of trenches and moats.

qae_pairs.question: Who built the Great Wall of China?
qae_pairs.explanation: Qianlong (Chien Lung) was the 2nd emperor of the Qing Dynasty (1644–1911) and extended the Ming Dynastys Great Wall. He extended the wall 8,100 miles and had 2,500 miles of trenches and moats.

Petra.passage: (see what the word means. In terms of what to do in Petra, the obvious attraction is the Treasury. I recommend it over the next week or so as it has some of the best facsimilies on the planet to be found in this one place. I took lots of pictures there and would highly recommend this. It’s possible to walk up to it and have a look, or there is a cable lift for $10. I went up it. Also at the entrance are some of the best photos ever from Petra, the most famous place is the large water tank/basin/lava stone on the right. I’m not really a big fan of lava stones and I find them more in the backcountry. I’d highly recommend this place if you are travelling to Petra. A night stay would be the best way to experience it and get away from the crowded area. I loved being away from all the crowds and I wish I could spend more time there. There is so much to see and explore.

qae_pairs.explanation: “The Treasury” is the most famous place in Petra. It is a large, ornately decorated, water tank/basin/lava stone. It is located at the entrance to the city and is a must-see for any visitor to Petra.

Colosseum.passage:
“The Colosseum, Colosseo or Colosseo Colosseo was the largest amphitheater in the world, constructed in 73 AD during the reign of Emperor Vespasian. It is located in the heart of the city and is a short distance from the Roman Forum. At its peak, it could seat an estimated 1,800,000 spectators. The Colosseum, Colosseo, or Colosseo Colosseo is the largest amphitheater in the world, constructed in 73 AD during the reign of Emperor Vespasian. The Colosseum has an exterior diameter of 410 meters (13,200 feet) and an overall circumference of 482 meters (1,570 feet). The Colosseum has been the subject of various archaeological excavations that have revealed the existence of several layers of stone slabs that were laid in the Colosseum over its history. This layer of stone was originally constructed as a retaining wall for the construction of the Colosseum, and it was later covered with lime plaster in order to create a white appearance. “
Here are the pictures of Colosseum. The Colosseum has a marble floor. You can see the intricate pattern in the floor when you get closer.

Machu Picchu.passage: It is a remarkable and intricate stone structure with intricate stonework and complex architectural features that were completed and constructed between AD 1440 and AD 1470, about four hundred years ago. Machu Picchu is located in the high Andes Mountains in Peru, near the Urubamba River. The city was built around 1440 AD by the Inca emperor Pachacuti, using limestone and granite stones. Machu Picchu has been constructed over more than three centuries by different Inca dynasties and kings, each of which was used to expand the city by adding new structures and temples. The city was destroyed by the Spanish conquistadors in 1532, and many of its structures were destroyed as a result. Machu Picchu's ruins and structures are covered in vegetation and lichens, but the city was rediscovered by archaeologist and historian Hiram Bingham in 1911, when he found evidence of a structure at the height of 1,100 meters above sea level. After a lengthy series of excavations and research, a comprehensive restoration of the city was begun by archaeologist Richard F. Wallis in 1980, and was completed by 1998. In the 15th century, Machu Picchu was rediscovered by the French archaeologist Françoise Grille.

qae_pairs.explanation: Machu Picchu is located in the high Andes Mountains in Peru, near the Urubamba River.

qae_pairs.explanation: Hiram Bingham was an American archaeologist, historian, and author. He rediscovered Machu Picchu in 1911.

qae_pairs.question: Who discovered Machu Picchu?
qae_pairs.explanation: Françoise Grille, a French archaeologist, rediscovered Machu Picchu in 1911.

Christ the Redeemer.passage: 'The. [1] The statue's creators, French sculptors Frédéric-Auguste Bartholdi and Alfred-Auguste Vischer, modeled Christ the Redeemer after a painting by the artist Charles-Augustin Beaulaincourt. [1] The statue stands atop Mount Corcovado, overlooking Rio de Janeiro. Its arms are outstretched to welcome visitors; its head is tilted downwards; and its feet face the city. The statue's base is adorned with a plaque inscribed with the name "Christo Redentor" (Christ the Redeemer) and the date "Cristo Rei" (Christ the Redeemer) in Portuguese. [2] The statue is 98 feet (30 m) in height. [1] The statue is carved out of marble. In 1758, when the statue was unveiled, there were some concerns about its safety and stability. To address these concerns, a "plank" was inserted behind the statue to serve as a foundation. [1] The statue became an attraction in the 1930s after the film adaptation of the 1889 book Christ Redeemer. This film is believed to be the only depiction of Christ in any film. The statue is one of the most visited monuments in the world. It is said to have inspired the 1850 novel A Tale of Two Cities by Charles Dickens.

Grand Canyon.passage: "The Grand Canyon is the most striking geologic feature in North America. It is a 277-mile-long and 18-mile-wide gorge carved by the Colorado River through the North American plateaus. The rim of the canyon is over 800 miles in circumference. It is about 6,000 feet deep. The average elevation is 4,000 feet, and the highest elevation in the park is over 6,800 feet. This makes the park the highest elevations in the American Rockies, and it is about 6,000 feet higher than the second-highest state, the South Dakota Badlands. "The canyon is part of the Sonoran Desert, which has one of the most diverse habitats in the country. The canyon has over 2,000 species of plants and 600 species of animal, the majority of which are unique to the area. Over 20 million people visit the park each year, and it generates over $1 billion for the local economy.

Sydney Opera House.passage: "The Sydney Opera House, designed by Jørgen Klit Nielsen, is the most iconic symbol of Sydney. It consists of two main performance halls, the Sydney Opera House Theatre and the Sydney Harbour Bridge Theatre. It is renowned as one of the world's leading opera houses, having become a symbol of the city. The opera house is situated on the shores of Sydney Harbour, at Bennelong Point. It is the home of the Sydney Symphony Orchestra and the Sydney Ballet, as well as several other companies. In 2010, the Sydney Opera House was named a UNESCO World Heritage site, alongside the Sydney Harbour Bridge. A 4.8km2, 1.6km deep harbour is also considered a major feature of the city. The Sydney Opera House is known for its spectacular views of the city skyline, particularly from the Sydney Harbour Bridge.

qae_pairs.question: What is the name of the point on which the Sydney Opera House is situated?
qae_pairs.explanation: Bennelong Point is the name of the point on which the Sydney Opera House is situated. It is located at the mouth of Sydney Harbour, and is named after the Aboriginal man Bennelong, who lived in the area in the 1780s. The point is also home to the Sydney Harbour Bridge, which is the main crossing point of the harbour. The Sydney Opera House is situated on the shores of Bennelong Point, and is a major landmark of the city.

qae_pairs.question: Who designed the Sydney Opera House?
qae_pairs.explanation: Jørgen Klit Nielsen is a Danish architect, who designed the Sydney Opera House. He was awarded the 2000 Sydney Design Award for the Sydney Opera House.

qae_pairs.question: Which is the most famous symphony orchestra in the world?
qae_pairs.explanation: The Sydney Symphony Orchestra is the most famous symphony orchestra in the world. It was founded in 1986 and is the leading performing arts organization in Australia. It has performed more than 1,000 concerts and has collaborated with more than 200 international conductors and artists. The orchestra is renowned for its performances of the worlds most popular classical music and opera. It is also the resident orchestra of the Sydney Opera House and the Sydney Harbour Bridge Theatre.

New Delhi.passage: New Delhi, India, has been the capital of India for more than a century. Although New Delhi is also a centre for the service sector, it has become a cultural hub with a diverse mix of people. Delhi is the seat of the supreme court, as well as the leader of the Indian Army. Shah Jahan.passage: Shah Jahan was the sixth emperor of the Mughal Empire and the son of the renowned Akbar the Great, founder of the Mughal Empire. [1] The Shah was born in 1492 and ruled over India until his death in 1657. [2][3] He took the title Padma-purushottama, which in Persian means 'Pride of a God'. [4] Shah Jahan ruled India during the reign of Akbar II, who had died on 19 December 1632, four months after giving birth to a son named Aurangzeb. Shah Jahan's mother was a Persian queen called Jodhpur who gave birth to a daughter named Nur Jahan, who was sent to Persia after her divorce from the Emperor, following which she was divorced from her own son who became a Muslim. [5] Shah Jahan was born to Jodhpur when the 12th emperor of the Mughal Empire was just 8 years old.

Treasury.passage: ." For me, Treasury is the name of the Australian Finance Minister, who is "Mr. Rudd" in our house. Treasury is Treasury House, in Canberra. Treasury is a "very" big building that I often take walks in, after school, or on the way home to my bus stop. I would never, in a million years, walk through the front door and ask for a job. I'm so sorry you couldn't attend Treasury's celebration last Friday - I was really looking forward to it. I was only able to do my part to help out, by walking the short walk up and down the steps of Treasury House. What is Treasury's birthday? How long has it been around? And what sort of job does the Treasury's leader, Mr Rudd, do? I'm sure these questions are often asked by people at Treasury, so here goes... The Treasury Building, Canberra, 15 June 2007. Photo by James Gillard of the Australian Government Department of Finance and Deregulation. The Australian Treasury has been around since at least the early 19th century, and more than 200 years have seen a huge number of changes, including 19th century reforms, through to today, when we have our current Minister for Finance (who is a former Governor of the Reserve Bank).

the Roman Forum.passage: "The Roman Forum was an essential focus of ancient Rome. It was constructed on a large scale and served as a forum for public life, meeting place, and marketplace. On December 12, 1931, the Brazilian president, Vargas, announced in Rio that the peak of the [mount] would be turned into a [national] monument (cjudo em). The height of the [mount] is 2,030 meters (6,561 feet). [The location of the monument is ]

The President also said that there would be no cost to the state, and would instead provide benefits to the construction of the monument and the expenses of the inauguration. The monument is 80 metres high (2,6 feet high), 10 metres high (32 feet) long and 2.5 metres high (8 feet) wide. [The statue itself] is made of concrete reinforced with steel columns. Rio de Janeiro.passage: “Rio de Janeiro is a metropolitan area and the capital of the state of Rio de Janeiro in Brazil. As the home of Brazil’s largest film studios and entertainment companies, as well as the main television transmitter of the country, Rio is the cultural and economic center of Brazil and one of the most visited cities in the world. In 2013, it was home to more than three million people, a number that is expected to reach 4.1 million in 2018. Rio de Janeiro was elected by UNESCO to be the next World Design Capital in 2014. As a center of excellence in the world of sport, Rio is home to the headquarters of FIFA, the international federation of association football, the headquarters of the International Olympic Committee and of the Pan-American Sports Confederation; of the Brazilian Confederation of Association Sports (CBDA) and other federations; of the Brazilian Institute of Sports; of the Brazilian Olympic training Center; and the Brazilian Football Federation headquarters. The city is also home to the biggest and most visited beach in the world, Copacabana, which sees about 8,000,000 visitors per year. Other beaches in the city are of similar names such as Posto 9, Prainha, and Arpoador. Rio de Janeiro is also home to one of the biggest film industries in the world.

the Colorado River.passage:
“The Colorado River is the main stream of the Colorado Plateau which traverses the western USA from the foot of the Rockies to the southern edge of the Mojave Desert in California. The river is currently 2,440 miles (3,360 km) long and can range in width from 500 feet (150 m) to over 1,000 feet (300 m). The Colorado is the second longest river in North America after the Missouri. The average depth of the river is between 4 and 20 feet. The headwaters of the Colorado River are located in the central Rocky Mountains of Colorado and Arizona, which are part of the Colorado Plateau. The lower basin stretches over 700 miles (1,130 km) and is located in the southwestern part of the United States.”
